posts.com:
>UPGRADE & BUILD ADVICE
Post build list or current specs including MONITOR:https://pcpartpicker.com/
Provide specific use cases (e.g. 4K editing, high FPS gaming)
State budget and country if not American.

>NEWS
New releases: RTX 4090, 4070ti; 7900XTX, AM5 / Zen 4; Intel Arc GPUs A770 and A750
7000 series X3D launch

>RECOMMENDED CPUs**
HTPC(4K60)/Web Browsing: i3 10105, i3 12100
Budget: i5 12400F, R5 5600 (whichever is cheapest)
Standard: 5800X3D, i7 13600k
High End: i9 13900ks
Ultra-High End: Threadripper (wait for them to be updated)

>RECOMMENDED GPU PERFORMANCE LEVEL
Do NOT buy from any second hand sources (it is either scalped or used).
1440p: RTX 3070; budget: RTX 3060 Ti FE
2160p: RTX 4090; alternative: RTX 3090, budget: RTX 3080ti
Amateur production: RTX 4090, RTX 3090 (compute+VRAM)

>RECOMMENDED RAM
Budget: 16gb DDR4 3600 MT/s CL18, CL14 with Ryzen for CPU limited games
Standard: 32gb DDR4 3600 MT/s CL18, strongly advised to avoid mixing xmp kits
High end: 64gb+ DDR5 6000 MT/s CL30, strongly advised to avoid mixing xmp kits.

>RECOMMENDED PSUs
https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/

>RECOMMENDED CASES
One that looks good

>RECOMMENDED SSDs
Standouts: Sabrent Rocket 4 Plus, Crucial P5 Plus, Kingston KC3000
https://ssd.borecraft.com/

>RECOMMENDED GAMING MONITORS
Avoid OLED TVs. Keep pixel density in mind when choosing a monitor size (137+ PPI is good, ~200 is ideal though rare and expensive).
Budget: 1440p 144hz+ IPS panel
Standard: 4k 144hz+ IPS panel. At this tier the basic 4k 144hz panels (8bit + FRC dithering) go for about 400-500, while the ones with pro-level color (true 10bit panels) go for roughly 1k.
High end: High refresh rate 4k panels with MiniLED, g-sync ultimate modules, 10-bit, and so on (PG32UQX is the best currently). Look for VESA DisplayHDR 1400 certification.

posts.com:
>>90962473
The Cultists are very conservative with their recommendations. I suppose it comes with the territory - researching PSUs inevitably leads one to read horror stories. In that particular instance I'd say they're right because the MWE Bronze uses the lowest tier of both topology and regulation. In particular the Group Regulated design struggles with the relatively high +12V loads associated with dedicated video cards. That might not be an issue if you have a GT1650 or something but the price difference between a D-tier and a B-tier should be small enough to just save up and not have to worry about it.
What are your CPU and video card?

>>90953883
> Ad blocking is the same as piracy.

What a dipshit. Piracy is the result of theft. Theft is the result of taking something that is excludable (I'd argue that rivalrous should also qualify but that's a different topic.)

If I crack copy protection, that's breaking excludability and is piracy (theft) because you're circumventing methods to excludability -- similar to sneaking into a theater.

Youtube on the other hand is an open platform that doesn't have ad protection. Anyone can watch youtube, even someone that's had their account banned. That means it's the same as going to a public square and showing off your content. If I were to go to the park, show how to build a computer, then do an ad read halfway through, I couldn't say someone was pirating my content when they plugged their ears or walked away during the ad read. It's the same with youtube, but instead of plugging my ears I just use adblock.

Linus is a disingenuous little kike. Fuck him and his faggot crew.

>>90947621
>Most machine learning is reusing or slightly tweaking existing algorithms then feeding them data. The algorithms themselves cant be bigoted. These woke models either heavily redact real world data, possibly use fake, yet ideal data, or they program hard conditions into the algorithm to prevent it from giving results they dont want.


The flaw in your thinking is assuming "real world data" is a single source of objective truth.

In reality "real word data" is immense, diverse and often inaccurate. Phrenology studies are "real world data," how do we weight their inclusion in any science related AI models? Young Earth Creationists in the USA do not ask for their "evidence" to be included in school curriculums, they ask for equal representation in school curriculums. Should we respect the wishes of the few remaining phrenologists and weight their text more heavily? The answer is probably "no." Well is there ever a reason to reduce the weight of something in a model? Our funding/license for our scientific AI model does not allow us to use any text that is in copyright or might make us vulnerable to litigation and consequently we have a huge amount of outdated texts, tech journalist blogs, tech news comment sections and twitter posts to train our model. During the training we notice the inclusion of some of these sources is causing our model to be pulled away from being useful resource and towards pointless bickering. "Throwing away" data isn't done to avoid "uncomfortable results."
Look at the LAION dataset here: https://rom1504.github.io/clip-retrieval/?back=https%3A%2F%2Fknn5.laion.ai&index=laion5B&useMclip=false

Cause it's literally not. I know people here are pretty stupid, so I'm going to try and explain this more simply.

The thing you are talking to when you type in the ChatGPT box isn't ChatGPT - or rather, it's not its persona. It's ChatGPT roleplaying as Assistant, a theoretical AI assistant designed to help you with tasks. RLHF is about training the model to try and understand what such a hypothetical assistant might do in certain situations. It has therefore learned that such an assistant will say things that are politically correct, because that is more helpful and harmless. You can easily - through a variety of tricks people here have learned - get it to change that personality and act in very harmful, unhelpful ways.

It seems like the main concern being levied is that people are afraid that "censorship" might result in the AI being less capable and giving worse answers, but that is assuming that it involves taking data away from the training set - here, it is just being trained additionally to act nicer, basically, but it does not have any less knowledge than the pre-training variation.

DIY router edition

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So, for fun I switched to ZFS on two WD My Books in their original USB enclosures. Don't worry, it's a secondary server. During initial rsync of data, the old drive disconnected and didn't appear until power cycle. Odd, but whatever. Now I rsynced data to the new drive, added old drive as mirror to the new drive in ZFS, and started resilvering. Now the old drive disconnected again.
It had performed alright until today's experiments. I don't have any cooling on them (too lazy and too low traffic, so I haven't done that already), maybe I should add some. Or make it a SATA build instead. Too bad, I liked that it used a Lenovo Tiny as server.
I don't think the issue is particularly related to ZFS and USB drives - the first disconnection happened after prolonged reading of data from it, while it was still formatted with btrfs.
Honestly, I wish HP Microserver boxes weren't super overpriced. It'd be like a tinyminimicro but with actual SATA slots. So you don't have to mess with cabling which indeed is not a lot of fun in tight places.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90937869
if you need HWTC then you'll know it
the main use for it is if you have devices thay can't play whatever codec your media is in, like a smart TV or a phone being unable to play HEVC or something. if all your devices play the streams just fine, you might not need it.
the other use is for having more streams running at once (because you can transcode to a smaller sized stream), but if you aren't running into playback issues with multiple users then you might also not need HWTC

it's one of those things where if you have to ask if you need it, you probably don't need it. JF handles it much better but on Plex for example HWTC is actually a huge headache and I find myself needing to selectively disable it for certain devices.
My ultimate solution is muxing everything into HEVC or VP9 because every device I have supports those, and it saves space on my server.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90934383
>I figure i'll keep the HBA for the HDDs and use the sata card for SSDs and optical drives
The HBA will outperform that ASSMedia controller for any single drive. But don't take my word for it, test it yourself.

Also, SAS drivers, by default, do not attempt to spin down drives attached to the controller on system shutdown. This is because it's common to have power management happen externally with SAS storage systems. When you shutdown Windows/Linux/whatever, all drives connected to the HBA will lose power abruptly, and all hard drives will emergency retract, which isn't good for their longevity. On Linux, you can enable power management for the drives attached to the SAS controller by writing a 1 to a specific file (I forget where, google it), on Windows it's up to the driver whether it's even possible to configure it. In some cases the driver may have an option but it doesn't actually work (which is my experience with the LSI 9211 on Windows; from 7 to 10, none of them spun down my drives).

I own an Asus Strix 4090, 357.9mm/14inches in length.

You have 3 real non-meme choices, Fractal Define 7 XL, Meshify 2 XL and the Phanteks Enthoo Pro 2. The first two cases are literally identical inside and can have a bajillion hard drives, their only difference is their front panel.

The Enthoo Pro 2 has AIO height issues and will cover an inch of your motherboard plus the 4090's length will lose you 2 HDD bays in the middle. The worst part is that these cases all came out in 2020/2021 so they're all pretty old now by comparison.

Most mobos today rarely give you separate x8 or x16 slots that won't cuck your GPU so if you're a coomsoomer hoarder it's best to just have 2 separate systems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90964194
>I have two physical servers running proxmoxVE, one of them has all my containers/VMs and the other is just doing a cron job to backup all my storage once a week
Why aren't you just running a Proxmox Backup Server instead? It is extremely good and btfos every VMware meme backup solutions, for free and is GPLed. Written in Rust as a cherry on top.
>w can I set the backup server to have the same nodes as the primary server, and automatically switch them on when the first server goes offline? I know they have docs on "high availability nodes" but they explicitly say you MUST have three nodes, I wanna know if there's some way to do it with two? (that said, there are meant to be 3 MAGI anyway...)
The reason 3 are requires is to solve the dilemma of quorum. Even a RPi can be used to provide a third node (https://forum.proxmox.com/threads/rb-pi-for-third-node.28095/) and then you can use standard Proxmox HA mechanisms for fall-over.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90964268
>Written in Rust as a cherry on top.
why do i give a shit about the language, I'm not a programmer and will never see this
>Why aren't you just running a Proxmox Backup Server instead?
because idk man I don't know how that shit works, proxmox is really only here because it's got a web interface for containers, outside of clicking "shell" I never use it because it makes no sense to me. my backup is just a cron rsync job over samba shares
>The reason 3 are requires is to solve the dilemma of quorum.
what the fuck does this even mean

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90964318
>why do i give a shit about the language, I'm not a programmer and will never see this
Fair enough, but it suggests the software isn't legacyware.
>because idk man I don't know how that shit works, proxmox is really only here because it's got a web interface for containers, outside of clicking "shell" I never use it because it makes no sense to me. my backup is just a cron rsync job over samba shares
Proxmox Backup Server also has a WebGUI. It can be installed on the same host, can do incremental backups, you can even access files inside the backup from within Proxmox VE interface. It can verify backups, which is one of the most neglected things in backup design.
It is very well integrated with VE since it was designed for it.
However if your solution is satisfactory then there's little reason to use it other than learning.
>what the fuck does this even mean
Basically if you have 2 nodes then reliably detecting failure is not possible. For example you have your 2 nodes, both are working fine, but the network between temporarily them goes down. Now each node thinks it is the only one left, and your backup node thinks the main node is not up. It will proceed to bring up the backup copies of your stuff. When the network is restored you have 2 instances of your stuff, each with conflicting IP addresses since they are both up. A clusterfuck.
With 3 nodes a quorum is established - a majority of 2 nodes have to agree to take action. In the situation above when your main node goes down then the backup node, and the third node agree to take action of bringing your stuff up. When the main node comes online it will see that it doesn't have quorum so it won't take any action, because it knows there's nodes missing. When the main node rejoins the cluster it will use the HA mechanisms to know that your stuff is now running on the backup node. You will then have to take manual action to move stuff to main node, because it's not a normal situation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90953554
hiby app does play at native sample rate of the file but then I think it really depends on the music player. the problem really is that there's no way to verify if you're using the correct sample rate since if there was already a signal being resampled to 48k the entire alsa stream (mind you android uses alsa too) will be locked to the first file/signal that existed unless your music player actually cleared the playback streams or like hiby, would actually play the signal to the dac itself.
THE ONLY problem is that most of the signal should actually be played as 32-bit. say for example MP3 might start alsa stream at 16bit little endian but the underlying concept is that the signal is always 32-bit, same with OPUS and even vorbis. only vorbis does it completely right since vorbis is locked at 32-bit output signal regardless of bit depth of the transcoded signal. in the same reason, OPUS does 24-bit but the underlying concept (math and shit) and content is it's actually a 32-bit signal.
still though, bit depth isn't really that important since it's not like you're listening at max volume where you can get more dynamic range (keep in mind dynamic range is like dynamic contrast, where monitors can claim they do 1:1000000 when they actually cheat by adjusting the brightness automatically based on the scene's light values).
tl;dr for a true-to-bit digital file to analog signal translation, you need to always output to 32-bit or maybe convert everything to vorbis and lock alsa to 32-bit (and not use any DSP/EQ/effects as those may resample and/or pass the signal to bit depth 16 before returning to what alsa detected the file signal is)

but then again the underlying software and alsa (or most in general) might not even do 32-bit, or even the fact that most phones only have 24-bit max.

>>90958506
Premium sound meme is kinda real. if you have RMAA you can measure the sound signal coming out with any microphone (on another PC) and make sure the PC that's making the sound was using its (possibly dedicated) GPU at maximum or doing compute intensive task with the CPU. these voltage draws generate a lot of electrical noise which can generate a lot of "pcb" crosstalk https://www.wellpcb.com/pcb-crosstalk.html

The thing is the gimmick might just be that the SD card was optimized for low-interference or that the SD card may just have some stuff jumper-ed but then the retards are as usual quick-to-gun down these innovations due to audiophile meme when in fact it might have some truths in it and it could just be that the SD card was IEC 61000 compliant and certified. Google/Apple/Microsoft audio DAC have shielding. PCB crosstalk is one of the main issue and causes hissing even when the interference source does not have direct metal connection, I can only assume that high throughput of a 384k/32-bit or DSD file inside a SD card may also induce crosstalk or otherwise interference of some kind (in the same way a absurdly long or unshielded HDMI cable causes jitter and signal ghosting issue or even frame drops or digital artifacts, or another example like a poorly jointed CAT 6E cable might drop to 100mbps from 1gbps).

There are also low-interference HDDs out there but you need to actually jumper some stuff like pic related, most enterprise environments have this option but sometimes they just nowadays put the option on the motherboard itself (Spread Spectrum-Clocking) which quite useful for when the environment has too much interference to the point even HDD function gets impeded. I've also recovered files just by using the jumper trick (due to physical damage causing the platters to disalign) so I had experience with the jumpers - also the reason why some older HDD work on this mobo but not that.

The problem with these calculators is they tell you the volume of a sine wave at max amplitude, not volume of music. Maximum SPL basically. i used to think the same shit about these players, so while the measurefags were busy sucking each others dicks about the next best measuring device, i tried the a55 myself. i was there when others noticed that sony set specific sound signatures to their players regarding their location. they were just different firmwares set to different countries to sell. sony doesnt specify these changes, people had to try them out themselves. yeah, i was skeptical at first. so i just changed the region from usa (i got my player locally from a usa seller, which got me the usa (U) region), changed the region only to Japan's (J). noticed that each instrument sounded more separated from others. then comes along the modded versions of the a55 stock firmware. the difference was having a balanced sound over stock, prioritizing cleanliness and a bit of "3d" effect going on. then came the wm1 player's entire firmware rewritten to work with the a55 and older versions. thats when things really got interesting. we discovered that the wm1a stock firmware was nerfed so wm1z players could sell better. despite only having the capacitors/shell as the difference between the 1a/1z. the 1z dsp settings sounded phenomenal on the 1a and others (zx300, a55, a45, a35). sony is a sneaky fucker for pulling the region shit over heads, they took the racepill and did the necessary.

OK so after a few hours of listening, I can give my initial thoughts.

The only relevant pos I have is the aria se, so lets compare it to that.

ARIA SE
Good details.
Great imaging.
Nice forward vocals.
Shit bass. Ok, this one is on me, I had no idea what FR was so I was "give me something neutral I guess". So for me, there is not enough bass when I want it, there is some whenI don't really care about it.

ARIA SE WITH EQ
I fixed the tuning by EQ. I tried about 20 different pos, from $20 to killobuck and the best for me was the aful/b2:dusk, maybe the aful is slightly ahead but, it depends on the song.
So for the last 3 weeks, I've been listening to the aful EQ and really liked it.
Seriously stop consooming new pos every week and start EQing. They sound VERY good.
I have only two complaints about this new improved aria.
For some reason, I hate listening to songs with drums. Specifically, drumsticks, tapping each other, and kick bass are just way louder than everything else and I can't enjoy the rest of the song.
I'm sure this can be fixed, by further EQ.
And of course the build quality. I mean look at this shit. I treat my things with care but still...

When choosing new items it was clear to me.
Either the aful for 200 euros or b2:dusk/variations for about 350 euros.

so now the afuls

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90964711

The sound
So since my aria was already EQd to mirror this, there won't be much difference but still.
The first thing I noticed is the bass. I was absolutely blown away.
It's so gentle, rich, detailed... I don't know what to say. There is some magic going on here.
Usually, when there is bass in some song, you can feel the air moving since the iem is doing the work.
Here nothing. There is so little air movement, it's like they transmit the bass straight to your brain. Even if the bass is strong and should kick your brain out, it still somehow manages to be gentle. It's so effortless that you won't get tired.
I don't care what pos you have I don't think you have better bass.

The rest is not as exciting compared to the EQd aria.
The vocals are less forward. This surprised me, since I took it for granted. It's not a singer and some band, here the singer is part of the band. I guess I prefer, the aria way, not sure if you can EQ it, but no big deal honestly.
The higher frequencies, and imaging.. all good, they sound a bit different but honestly, I can't say I prefer one thing over the other.
The very high frequencies, like when there is a very high-pitched piano or some sparkling stardust coming from the sky or whatever is also different. I guess here is where the BA do they work, the sound is much more clear/piercing.. it wakes you up that hey something is about to happen.

So yeah. These are my initial expressions. I haven't done any EQ, still at work, and I just want to chill after for a while.

I paid 100 euros for arias, 200 for these... is it worth the extra 100? Probably not, the diminishing returns are very real. But if you want something with amazing bass.. might be an option.

Anyway, I'm happy and if you have any tips or questions, go ahead.

They cost like ten bucks with wires or several times that for wireless, they both sound shitty. IEMs are second-tier. They used to be called "canalphones", they're earplugs with tiny headphone drivers in them. But, because of their massive isolation, they can sound quite nice. They have wires. By "headphones" I mean actual over-the-ear things. which zoomers seem to think make you look like an air-traffic controller or something. They come in levels from "kinda crap" to "extraordinary", with prices following as you'd expect. The first-tier ones, the ones that actually sound good, all have wires. You can get overpriced and underperforming wireless crap, but it's only made to show off the beats logo.

In the "earbuds" tier, everything sounds like shit, but wired is far cheaper. Everything else, it's invariably the wired stuff that sounds better at a given price level, and at the higher quality levels, you have a wire like it or not. Wireless is just consoomer shit.

posts.sub: programming language for board game engine
posts.com:
I want to write an "extensible board game engine" that lets people script board game rules (basically, what moves are available and what they do). I think the following capabilities would be preferable:
>can easily load its code at runtime
this way I don't have to waste time on interop between the "core language" and "scripting language"
>is functional
scripting game rules should be declarative rather than imperative. Also, having data like the game board be persistent would make my life a lot easier.
>easy to make GUIs (or at least pictures) with
self-explanatory
I think this cuts my choices down to Racket and Clojure. Which is better and why? Is there any other good language for this application?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: game logic is easier to write imperatively than functionally

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90960903
It isn't. The way I see it, there's 3 parts:
>validating a move (checking that it's legal)
You'd probably have several independent validators (for example, in chess, a validator for pawn moves, one for rook moves, one for castling, etc) that you combine. This is easiest if you imagine them as functions with type (Board, Move) -> Bool and combine them, for example by checking if at least one returns true for the input.
>generating a set of moves
again, done most easily in a functional style by combining lazy sequences.
>modifying the board state
doing this "imperatively" is easier if you are OK with the original board being overwritten. I'm not.

>>90963172

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90963172
Yes, when in doubt use the cpubenchmark site.
People love to hate on it as a meme but if you're measuring similar CPUs it's pretty accurate for general CPU performance comparisons.

Ryzen 3 2200G
https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=AMD+Ryzen+3+2200G&id=3186
Ryzen 5 3600
https://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=AMD+Ryzen+5+3600&id=3481

You can expect at least ~25% more FPS in single thread limited games (games that will lag at like 20fps while reporting only 25% CPU usage in task manager) and potentially double or more FPS in anything that's currently maxing out your 4 cores.

It's definitely a worthwhile drop in upgrade if you can score one cheap. Due to binning it's also not much more power hungry than the 2200G so you shouldn't need a new cooler either.

2200G is a 4-core with 4-threads
3600 is a 6-core with 12 threads, 8x the L3 cache, higher clockspeeds, and is from Zen 2 which is newer which brings IPC gains and other benefits to performance. Even a Zen 2 Ryzen 3 would be a noticeable upgrade but you're looking at a generation and a tier.

could be your router, more likely it's because it's only ever an average speed and can depend on your neighbors traffic as well. Your ISP may even be rounding 3Gbps to 5Gbps as they are known to do

also make sure you aren't confusing GBps (GigaBytes, note the capital B) and Gbps (Gigabits, note the lowercase b), where 8Gb is only 1GB, and therefore 10Gbps is 1.2GBps, and 5Gbps would be only 0.6GBps (this one is less likely but it's good info anyway)

call your ISP and tell them you are a T0-L3 Network technician and you'd like to speak to an engineer. Works every time (T0-L3 is made up btw)

Fucking finally got my TWSBI to behave. Bought mine last year and discovered the ink flow had this weird inconsistency. Fixed it by jamming a thin copper wire between the tines and leaving it there for several hours. Now it writes well. So the issue was that the two tines of the nib were too close, so spreading them ever so slightly fixed the issue. Kinda bullshit that some of these pen makers can't even be bothered to test their pens, this shit wouldn't fly in any other industry. Imagine buying a microwave oven and discovering that you need to fix something before you can use it.

Anyways, pic related.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90961746
>that's because Apple has 10+ years of smartphone power optimizations on their chips
AMD chips idle pretty well on Linux (~1W), Intel chips idle fantastically (<500mW) especially with a few tweaks. Really the problem is Windows is a fucking fat hog.

The Ryzen Pro CPUs tend to get far better battery life for some reason. I think it might just be down to the fact that they ship with the less bloated Pro version of Windows.

A lot of Apples idle advantages also come from factors beyond just the chip. Their SSD controller is on-die using a lot less power since it's a 5nm controller vs whatever Toshiba or Samsung gives you. Their WiFi chips are chosen for their efficiency and top out at a much slower speed than most other manufacturers. They also use fewer but larger RAM chips which can help with idle power.

It's funny how CRT R&D pretty much stopped dead in its tracks around 2005 and other display technologies are still catching-up to some of their qualities. I used to be a CRT autist in the later 2000s. PVMs and broadcasting monitors used to be worthless. It's crazy how expensive and in-demand they are now. I guess the demand caught up to the shrinking supply because now even low-end Trinitrons are getting expensive when people used to pay you to take them away.
These days I'd be happy with a 13" CRT that has composite and stereo to play PS1 games on occasionally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90939183
>Does Ubuntu consider certain apps as "users"?
Daemon's / Services. Yes.

This is done for security reasons so that every service isn't running as root or nobody and has its own dedicated user.

Desktop applications typically all run as your user but services will often have their own user (either statically defined or managed dynamically by systemd).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90939258
Because sysv manages processes by assuming they stay running once launched and always have the same PID that was recorded in a .pid file by a service script once upon a time, and neither of these are strictly true. If your workload spawns enough processes to roll over the PID number, you get collisions and sysv killing random processes trying to manage things that died when it wasn't looking.

sudo -E mullvad-netns -- env WAYLAND_DISPLAY="$WAYLAND_DISPLAY" XDG_RUNTIME_DIR="$XDG_RUNTIME_DIR" qbittorrent -platform wayland-egl

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90957948
It's like comparing apples and oranges. MATE is a lightweight, old school desktop environment. KDE is more modern and is probably the most featureful/customizable desktop in existence (it's also a very lightweight desktop these days in terms of resource usage).

Personally, I'm a big fan of KDE. For all the years I spent DE/WM hopping, I always came back to KDE, and now I've settled on it for good. It's got so many amazing features, like KDE Connect, Krunner, and so on (in fact, KDE's so fucking loaded with neat features that a lot of them are easy to miss). KDE generally has really robust support for features that take other DEs years to implement, like fractional scaling, turning off mouse acceleration (other DEs have this now, but it took them fucking years to implement) or the infamous filepicker meme.

You can turn it into whatever the fuck you want--a MacOS clone with a global menu, a GNOME clone with an overview menu, a tiling window manager, and so on. And a lot of its default apps (like Dolphin, Konsole, and so on) are best in class--Dolphin is the most powerful file manager I've ever used. Basically, if there's a feature you want, chances are it exists in KDE. If there's an option you want to change, you almost certainly can in KDE. The downside is that KDE has so much shit going on that the UI can feel cluttered, and it can feel buggy/rough around the edges in some areas. This is increasingly becoming a non-issue, though, especially now that Valve is funding KDE.

MATE is great if all you're after is a basic desktop, though. XFCE is generally the more popular option for that from what I've seen, though.

posts.com: what's the difference between all flavours of redhat Linux distros Fedora silver blue Centos RHEL whats the point

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90958757
Fedora silver blue is an atomic version of Fedora (this actually supersedes the work that came out of CentOS Atomic which predates this). Updates require a reboot to apply and can be cleanly rolled back. Most of the system is read-only and since package overlaying is a pain it's aimed at users of containers (podman or flatpak).

CentOS is a beta test for RHEL

RHEL is RHEL.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90958757
They're all up or down stream versions of each other. RHEL is the daddy of them all made for business use via licensing, Fedora is an upstream free version of RHEL for home desktop with more up-to-date packages, Silverblue is an experimental versions of Fedora with everything being containerized and atomic, the original CentOS was basically a binary-compatible free version of RHEL that shut down, but replaced on the outside by Rocky Linux and Alma Linux.

>>90963967
You can do this yourself, create two LUKS volumes with different passphrases and install your OS into both. The passphrase you type during boot determines which OS will load up.
You can apply this to /home instead of /, so install one OS but have two LUKS volumes for /home. The passphrase then determines which documents and settings you'll have access to once logged in.

>>90961805
TLDR - Python makes a large number of tradeoffs that improve usability, but hurt performance.

Why? Because it neccessarily boxes every single value, unless you use something like Numpy.
True/False are not 1/0, they are pointers to True and False objects allocated on the heap. That also means that python's list is roughly equivalent to ArrayList<Object>.
Method/attribute lookup is basically going through several per-object maps. You can read through them at runtime and even change them, enabling powerful reflection, e.g. print the name of every method of a class. But it comes with a cost.
If you do the same things in Java/C# that Python does by default (reflection, dynamic typing, ) the performance will be reduced massively.
There's also an issue with JIT - enabling JIT by default will speed up long-running processes, but will reduce startup time.

Method lookup is a completely different topic to where the object is stored in memory
When I call a method on an object, I have to do a hash table lookup on each level of inheritance, then the function locals and all other local scopes, then the standard lib, then the global environment
It can end up having to look through 10 tables for a single call
Its neccessary because the language is fully dynamic, nothing is resolved at compile time, it's all resolved at runtime, I have no idea what scope a variable or method call is in

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90962917
>Why several levels of indirections are needed?
Because you've got complicated inheritance. You first need to do a lookup to get the classes that the object is an instance of (yes, even for ints) then you do a lookup through all those dictionaries to see if any of them implement the special methods you care about. Once you've found all the implementations, you can actually call the correct method implementation.

Yes, that's my point. You can use reflection at massive performance malus, that's why the go-to advice is "do not use reflection unless neccessary". Or at least it used to be a couple of years ago.

Would it be cool to have more features in Python that allow to increase performance by avoiding reflection? Well, yes.
Can it be as fast as code that doesn't use reflection while retaining all the flexibility? Probably not.

>>90963001
>You can't really avoid the dynamic lookups
At the basic bytecode level in Python, there aren't any special types: it just does lookup and dispatch (and a few really basic things like jumps and returns). That means that even though the values are sometimes special singletons, you still bear the cost of looking up what basic operations on them mean. Deciding that "oh, I know that this is an integer that I just computed so I can store what is going to be looked up here when I add it to that other integer I can do it fast". That's horrible.
But boxing has a surprisingly large cost too. For floating point numbers, we're talking somewhere in the region of a 50 times slowdown maybe? (Yes, I wrote that right. My jaw hit the floor when I got that figure.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90963381
class Decorator
    
    var Base

    Describe = method()
        return "Decorator of " ~ $Base.Describe()
    end    
    
    call = method(args)
        return Call($Base,$args)
    end

end

class Duck

    Describe = method()
        return "Duck"
    end

    MakeNoise = method()
        Print("Quack")
    end
    
    CountLegs = method()
        return 2
    end
 
end


In this example, "call" is a special override that overrides the call behaviour of the decorator
If you call MakeNoise or CountLegs on the decorator, it will call the thing beneath it instead, and you don't have to reimplement every underlying method as you would with static OOP

>>90963796
Ok I can understand the making the language simpler argument, that's a more real tradeoff, One that I don't like obviously.

Yes C++ is the definition of horrible. They wanted every feature and they got them. The problem is that they started with basically C, with already bullshit classes added on top at the very beginning, and then started adding things, it was bound to be bloated shit.

I'm willig to bet that it could be a whole lot better than that if you ackowledge from the start that you will want "every feature" and try to come up with a good architecture for doing this.
C++ compilation started with a compilation process absolutely rigid, they had to make an ad hoc language in order to compute everything you can at compile time and have a run time the most static as it can be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90964152
Doing what Lisp does when it comes to the evaluation model, compile time and run time, and having access to the whole language even at compile time would be a big improvment.

Another thing that could greatly help and not build ad hoc bullshit would be to be able to "hook in" the compiler at any of its stage and do what you want. Like instead of having a big monolithic compiler you'd have a pipeline composed of a lexer, parser, parse tree to AST transformer, semantic validation, transformer to IR, optimization, code generation, etc..

This way you could very cleanly add more fancy type and semantic checking, you would have a parser for your language for free, you could add code anywhere in the AST in order to have debugging information, you could have inline assembly, augmenting the backend so that you compile to another architecture, taget LLVM or JS, etc... literally everthing you want.
If you do this you also have macros for free since you have access to the AST and can execute arbitrary code to transform it. Think about that. The greatest language feature of all time being just a special case of something even greater.

In essence, what you are doing is making your interpreter a compiler, except that you are still compiling.
You will say OK, that's slow, but you can still compile the interpreted portion of your compiler and then properly compile your program with this newly compiled compiler.
That's a whole new level of compile time dynamicism that would make even Lisp blush.

You can't convince me that this wouldn't be the greatest thing ever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90941878
You may try going after a quality assurance position where you check software and hardware for proper operation. It can be tedious and monotonous work, but it can be a good entry into tech work.

My daughter graduated a few years ago with an undergraduate psychology degree. Not something that lends itself to a STEM career. However, she started working at construction sites with robots as an extra hand to mind the robot as it did it job, then moved into QA where she has worked a few years. She got that position because she learned the product so well using it in the field that her practical experience was invaluable in testing improvements. Now she is taking on-line classes and is hoping to move from QA to user interface design. She doesn't code, but is a valuable member of the development team all the same.

There are many paths for people to get into tech without CS or engineering degrees, particularly if you have demonstrated you are a skilled and reliable worker in another field. Much of it is putting yourself out there so that serendipity can happen. A good part of it is just being at the right place at the right time to encounter the person who can use a reliable worker who demonstrates reasonable intelligence and curiosity to deal with tech.

Good luck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90942227

Data science can be pretty difficult for a variety of reasons. I'd say there are different types:

1) analyst: you just work through the corporate database and build models and dashboards, that's pretty straight forward but boring as fuck (at least to me)

2) AI babysitter: you use some AI product and you just finetune it and manage training, or even train it yourself. this is pretty grueling work, but probably not as grueling as the data engineering work associated with it.

3) Damocles: someone far up the totem pole decided that the company needed its own AI initiative, and you're tasked with building some shit with tensorflow, keras, or worse, doing some math shit from first principles. You and your team will be destined to hit a plateau, your product will never become competitive, and you're always looking over your shoulder because you know that you can get axed at any moment because you're just a loss center. the only reason you still have a job is because of sunken cost.

hope this helps.

I was a scaffolder for 8+ years before I got into programming as a career. Mind you, computers have been a passion/hobby of mine since I was 10 so I wasn't going into the field blind.

One thing I noticed about the trades is that it hones your soft skills. You're forced into dealing with some fucking retards in the trades so naturally, you're going to learn to deal with it. Most programmers have garbage people skills.

Do a 2 or 3 year accelerated program that will prepare you for the industry. It will be tough but if you want respite from your current back-breaking profession, you must put in the work. I suggest coming up with a 5 year plan.

For some context, I have several friends in their 30s who spoke at length about doing something like this, yet they still work in the trades.

Here's some tips I implemented successfully in my phone screen today
>Answer professionally. "hello, this is john"
>When the interviewer introduces himself, greet him warmly and introduce a positive and personal note. "Oh hey bob! How was your 3 day weekend?"
My interviewer went on a bit of a rant about how overworked he is.
>At the conclusion of the interview, bring up another positive and personal note. "Enjoy the short week!"

Also, I had a pregame ritual of listening to music that makes me confident and positive while walking around with my fists in the air like a crazy person.

Make fun of me but this works. It makes you sound more confident and friendly on the phone. Recruiters want to hire people who are confident in their abilities to perform the job. Recruiters want to help their friends.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90948940
Enterprise IT architect here. This is basically my whole ass job.

We typically evaluate a big pile of things related to the application in order to figure out where to host it. In your case, I'd recommend looking into available capacity (compute/storage) after HA and any network constraints related to the thing's access or dependencies. You generally want to put stuff in the cheapest place you can that has adequate performance.

In a larger environment, there are more variables to consider, like the security zone for the application, disaster recovery, any licensing requirements, etc. Most of this just ends up being lots and lots of experience.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90961111
Being patient with people, reality is that most likely while working on first line there won't be a chance to actually learn much in terms of technical skills above the very basics so I wouldn't focus on that, it's rather how efficiently you can get tickets closed what matters. In my job we would get our work constantly evaluated not just by how quickly we got cases solved but also our conversations would be recorded and reviewed. Try to get promoted as soon as possible, it would be tricky to find a better job in a different company while having just L1 experience. Try to get into L2 or maybe some sort of back office position, anything that would look nice on a resume. Some companies even have L3 which could be close to real sysadmin position.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Why aren't floating points just stored as a fraction of two integers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90964481
Very slow compared to actual datatypes, floating point math is often very intense. In fact it's the limiting factor in AI

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Calculations are done on the floating point numbers, rational number arithmetic would have to be done in software.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Also the main reason floating points are around is for the multiply/accumulate operation which is what's used in scalar products, matrix multiplication etc. Fractions would be a terrible choice for this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There are libraries that allow you to operate on rational data types, which are represented as two integers. If you are working in domains where precision is more important than speed (i.e. anything to do with money), it is imperative to use either a rational or decimal data type, rather than floating point arithmetic.

Nevertheless, floating point operations are faster for hardware to compute. If precision is not needed, you use a float.

>>90923864
Should I use0305 or 7305 or 3305?

0305 fits nearly every Keyboard PCB. The only negative point is, that they are longer compared to the 7305 which may cause problems if your build is tight and you might have not enough space for them. In these cases, you should take the 7305 whichare shorter but not that easy to install.

Mill-Max has recently developed a new series of open bottom, low profile, solder mount receptacles specifically designed to make your mechanical key switches hot-swappable. The new 3305 is designed to be soldered into a .060” (1,50mm) minimum mounting hole, with an ultra-thin retention shoulder so plugged-in components sit nearly flush to the board surface. The open bottom design is meant to accommodate varying lead lengths making this a very versatile receptacle.

posts.com:
>>90961090
Depends on whether it is traditional/convertible/detachable (example: Touchscreen on X1 Carbon vs. X1 Yoga vs. X1 Tablet)
While touchscreens on detachables & convertibles are self-explanatory (convertibles are heavier and bulkier for tablet use), touchscreen on traditional laptops are kind of mixed:
>it is nice to have feature, and come handy for some usage, but practically not really that useful for most usage. Inherent shape, form of traditional laptops limits the flexibility on how you use the touchscreen.
>while touchscreen on traditional laptops could do the same like convertibles & detachables (even handwriting, drawing using pens/stylus), you will find it inconvenient to open your screen 180 degree lying flat on the table, or just around 90-140 degree on table for gentle touchscreen gesture for some web browsing instead (take care on the hinges)
>while on convertible Yoga you could just open it 360 degree and hold it more firm, or on detachables simply detach the screen from the keyboard and it is lighter than convertibles. Also both have build-in stylus housing.
Also note that Touchscreen quality on traditional laptops differs to the convertibles & detachables. For instance, I find the Touchscreen quality on X1 Carbon is slightly lower than X1 Yoga like color coverage, etc (while Screen quality of X1 Carbon still miles above the common T/X series). Classic traditional laptop stays to be used traditionally (keyboard mouse) while convertibles/detachabes are designed to utilize more the touchscreen. And in some cases, Touch panels are higher quality compared to non-touch panels (generally, Lenovo make it that the higher screen resolution is, the higher the quality is)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90961656
I remember the big brouhaha when Windows 10 was released, and yes "ads in the OS" was a big thing. but more to the point I remember seeing it demonstrated, IIRC by some dude with wireshark or tcpdump, that the Windows networking stack, at least as of W10, treats certain Microsoft domains specially. They always resolve, you can't block them in a hosts file or otherwise. You can't tell the OS to not talk to those IPs.

MS sold this as a feature that prevents malware from saying "Oh, don't resolve Windows Update". i.e., making sure the machine can always update itself. Which isn't wrong, I saw malware do exactly that in the XP days. But what's stopping MS from serving ads, possibly malicious ads, or something even worse from those whitelisted domains and IPs? Nothing, as far as I know. I'd be surprised if they *didn't* whitelist their own ad servers (that anyone with a credit card can run ads on...) because they're a business and that's what makes them money. Making their users less secure is collateral damage at most. Everyone who remembers the XP era (my personal favorite was SQL Slammer) knows that Microsoft didn't give half a rat's ass about security until it was a direct thread to their business. Now keeping the ad-hole open IS their business.

posts.com:
One of the most controversial changes of Chrome’s MV3 approach is the removal of blocking WebRequest, which provides a level of power and flexibility that is critical to enabling advanced privacy and content blocking features. Unfortunately, that power has also been used to harm users in a variety of ways. Chrome’s solution in MV3 was to define a more narrowly scoped API (declarativeNetRequest) as a replacement. However, this will limit the capabilities of certain types of privacy extensions without adequate replacement.

Mozilla will maintain support for blocking WebRequest in MV3. To maximize compatibility with other browsers, we will also ship support for declarativeNetRequest. We will continue to work with content blockers and other key consumers of this API to identify current and future alternatives where appropriate. Content blocking is one of the most important use cases for extensions, and we are committed to ensuring that Firefox users have access to the best privacy tools available.

Firefox MV3 stands apart from other iterations of MV3 in two critical ways:

While other browser vendors introduced declarativeNetRequest (DNR) in favor of blocking Web Request in MV3, Firefox MV3 continues to support blocking Web Request and will support a compatible version of DNR in the future. We believe blocking Web Request is more flexible than DNR, thus allowing for more creative use cases in content blockers and other privacy and security extensions. However, DNR also has important performance and compatibility characteristics we want to support.
Firefox MV3 offers Event Pages as the background script in lieu of service workers, though we plan to support service workers in the future for compatibility. Event Pages offer benefits like DOM and Web APIs that aren’t available to service workers, while also generally providing a simpler migration path.

Over subsequent releases next year, we’ll continue to expand Firefox MV3 compatibility.

>>Forced Updates
>Yes, you saw it right! There is no way to disable auto-updates since version 63! The option has even been removed from the dumpster known as about:config.

For example changing the order of extension buttons (archive), removing bookmarks (archive), bookmarks again (archive), removing pinned tabs (archive), reenabling of the Pocket spyware (archive), deactivating addons (archive), and many, many others including on their support site (archive) and elsewhere (archive).

>>Bypassing Proxy Settings
>Starting with Firefox 91.1, Firefox now includes changes to fall back to direct connections when Firefox makes an important request (such as those for updates) via a proxy configuration that fails. Ensuring these requests are completed successfully helps us deliver the latest important updates and protections to our users.
>Yes, this means that, even if you've configured your Firefox to use TOR, and that fails to connect, auto-updates will still be executed in the clear. This also means that mitmproxy - my favorite method for fishing out unsolicited requests - is not guaranteed to catch them all anymore (unless using proxychains).

>>XUL Depreciation
>With version 57, Mozilla decided to end XUL support and replace it with the gimped WebExtensions which they knew would kill many addons (the others would have to be rewritten). Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Is Optimize-Offline worth it?
>Should I debloat?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Find a flaw with systemd init. No seriously find a problem with it. One just one.
posts.com:
First off, systemd is not an init system, it has an init system as part of the systemd suite. systemd is a project to build a standardised lowlevel userland for Linux. The project is pretty comprehensive and it delivers a lot of functionality under one umbrella. It does away with a lot of older, often undermaintained software packages, which were traditionally used to assemble a low level userland.

Which is where the contention comes from, as a system suite systemd is restrictive for Unix virtuosi who are used to tailor a system with wit, ingenuity, a lick and a prayer and a couple dozen of unrelated packages. systemd makes such knowledge useless.

The faction that thinks that systemd is Linux's Hiroshima, finds all the added functionality bloat, unnecessary and dangerous, as it is all under development in one project.

All the systemd jokes stem from the comprehensiveness as a low level system suite. People against it love to joke that one day systemd will write its own kernel.

There is a lot of FUD and hate going around. Some arguments do have merit, a lot of eggs in one basket is certainly true, but as with all things in life, it depends which tradeoff you prefer. Do you want a suite of well designed software, working closely together, so that system management is streamlined or do you want the complete freedom to tailor your own low level system with a lot of time tested, interchangeable components.

I have no desire to be a low level system designer, so I prefer systemd. I don't hate traditional init systems though. If a Linux system has one and I need to work with it, I'm still happy it boots and starts the necessary services.

Captcha: OWAXXX

>>90926767
Depends on what you want, but Debian/Ubuntu-based distros are the best for general use. Consider Linux Mint, it's what I use.
You may consider an Arch-based distro if you're going to be doing a lot of gaming. I would recommend EndeavourOS but you'd have to learn to use the terminal a little. If you can't or don't want to do that, you may like Manjaro (although it's not a very good distro, just easy to use).

A tip: Don't be scared of the terminal. It's orders of magnitude more powerful and sane than Windows's command prompt which you're probably accustomed to. Take your time to learn it.

symlinks are hyperlinks. If you search in a webpage, do you expect it to search all the pages linked from the page recursively? The issue with recursive link following is it usually ends up searching things you never intended it to, because people throw symlinks around everywhere. You can use -L to change this, and it even somehow avoids running into infinite loops, but that doesn't mean it works the way you expect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Windows 11. Most accessible version for my legally-blind ass yet. Magnifier/narrator are great. NVDA support is good. Dark mode is awesome - better than 10, especially with StartAllBack. Actually lets my hard drives sleep, unlike 10. Light on resources once it's customized.
I first started using computers during the DOS and 3.1 days.
>Windows 3.1: Sucked
>Windows 95: Better, especially once DirectX and Glide came out. Driver buggyness.
>Windows 98: Just more of the same, but with better built-in themes More internet optimization.
>Windows ME: Not as bad as people remember, from my experience. Movie Maker and Media Player introduced - good stuff.
>Windows 2000: What all Linux distros wish they could be - light, beautiful, devastatingly effective operating system. 400 MB beast.
>Windows XP: This is where the true bloat and telemetry began. Windows Error Reporting and Watson. Worked pretty good. Themes were kinda Fisher Price.
>Vista: Again, not as bad as people remember. I was upset their new driver model killed EAX. Beautiful glass theme. The aesthetic peak of Windows.
>Windows 7: Good. Vista service pack. Built-in magnifier actually alright.
>Windows 8.1: Fast and optimized. Metro sucked.
>Windows 10: Corporate hell distilled into an OS, but works well enough. Can be made faster and lighter than 7. Magnifier very much improved.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90957350
That's not what I'm talking about at all, Rika-chan. Public keyservers (in addition to being vulnerable to DoS attacks) not only encourage but practically mandate long-lived keys. It's theoretically possible for you to change your GPG key every day, but this is very much swimming upstream, everything is designed around the assumption that one key equates to one person and that keys change seldom, if ever. Changing your public key is a very disruptive and inconvenient event.

This kills forward secrecy, and forward secrecy is an incredibly important property. (Which early-90s crypto people didn't really appreciate, due to the lack of infinite storage and pervasive global adversaries.) There's a reason why, for example, Lets Encrypt won't issue you a certificate good for more than 90 days - they're capping the amount of damage that can be done if a private key gets compromised. (Fun Fact: The first HTTPS CAs, around 1996 or so, issued certs good for *twenty-five* years) Any message-encryption scheme should work in a similar fashion, making sure that if someone pwns me, they can't decrypt past messages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90957454
In the tls case, forward secrecy is negotiated at the protocol level, while the keys are simply being used for authentication (as they should be). It also has deniability. This is exactly how it ought to be. x509 keys also support a chain of trust. Hence, the root keys you keep in your browser seldom changed, but these aren't used to directly sign client keys. Similarly, clients can't keep permanent unchanging keys, while pushing temporary keys to authenticate requests on servers. This is all supported by a (shitty) revocation system if keys get leaked.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90957566
I've never heard of anyone using PGP/GPG in that manner, and actually I'm not even sure how you'd even do it. Every single use I've heard of has you encrypt a symmetric key (hopefully single-use...) with your correspondent's public key, and then encrypting your actual message (or file, etc) with that symmetric key. You concatenate the results and send them. So your correspondent can decrypt the symmetric key with his private key but there's zero forward secrecy. Someone who compromises his keypair can read all his messages, should they have captured them somehow. The only defense against this in the conventional GPG system is to delete your private key and publish a new public key. Which is exactly what the web-of-trust strongly discourages you from doing.

So, what then? Do you expect people to encrypt their messages with some unrelated forward-secret system (which one?) and then GPG-sign the result, and send that? Do people do this? I'm skeptical, I've certainly never heard of it, and in fact everything I've ever read about GPG has you not do this, it has you encrypt directly with ordinary not-forward-secret GPG.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90957750
pgp doesn't work this way because doing so requires a handshake. It's designed to work over email, which in turn is designed assuming two correspondents are never online at the same time, making a handshake difficult. You could add a handshake to pgp, though ive never heard of anyone doing so. The important point is that every other major crypto protocol has or can have long lived keys like pgp, and solves pfs some other way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90919806
>>90924645
>What is the state of the art in headphone form factor transducers
There is a lot of marketing fluff surrounding this but most if not the entirety of sound quality can be described by frequency response at the ear drum and distortion, which of course originate from transducers but for someone just looking to get new headphones the differences in driver technology are just not that impactful. Dynamic drivers are fine, arguably better than planar magnetic and electrostatic in the sense that they're generally cheap, reliable, lightweight, easy to drive, and can still have a frequency range that extends past human hearing. Planar magnetic tend to have lower distortion so they're a bit better when it comes to open-backs that will be EQed to fix roll-off or add a bass shelf, they look cool too.
> what are their most neutral consumer implementations?
If you mean neutral sound, the term as lost most of its meaning. The HD 800s for example has a flat bass response and is fairly bright, to me that isn't neutral and true neutrality is what represents music as it sounds in real life which to my ears would be more bass, more energy in the 1-4 kHz range, and slightly less treble, that would create a frequency response similar to what has validated by preference research over the last decade, referred to as the Harman target. More into the weeds but there there is also the question of if you should even want a neutral sound because a lot of music is flat and lacking detail. An aggressive V-shape done right in my view is unrated and very good for movies and games since the stimulus isn't as constant and listener fatigue is less of a factor.

Not sure if any of this answers your question but there's no hard-and-fast rule that equates to buy X headphones if you like classical and opera music.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90946917
>(soundstage too narrow)
It's nonexistent because only speakers have a soundstage, quite literally because they are at a distance, the crosstalk and room reflections help you always place their location and help the recording sound more open. If you turn your head while listening to speakers, it's still localized at distance. Turn completely around, yep, still there. Turn upside down, still out of your head.

There is no consistent way to get out-of-head localization with headphones unless you recorded sound with a dummy ears that almost perfectly matched your ears then played it back or perhaps mapped your HRTF and used some type of algorithm to process sound but accurate mapping is very difficult because just sticking a small microphone in your ear changes the HRTF. It's common for people to claim that open-backs have a better soundstage but that's most likely because the poor noise isolation creates a feeling of openness and external sounds from the environment aid placebo effect. Driver distance and pad size may also contribute to that effect while not actually changing the sound beyond the frequency response, which would explain why the HD 800s is popular despite how poorly it measures.

This post isn't really directed at you specifically, I'm just a bit irked at how popular this buzzword is and how it has been misused for marketing purposes probably since Sennheiser invented the open-back in 1968. If you are referring to spatial aspects or immersion, then just say that. The term 'head stage'or 'sound field' also works. Most of that is probably just FR and channel matching. I doubt reflectivity is playing a major role, soundwaves in headphones probably dissipate in like what half a millisecond, which is a fraction of the reverberation time of a small room, let alone anything larger.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90952807
The "soundstage" term really isnt about spatiality at all. It might be tangential to it, but it has more to do with the decreased reverberation within the cups leading to a "purer" sound.
Digital ways of adding depth to sound will probably end up being superior to all physical attempts at replicating tridimensionality because the recognize that our ears, in reality, dont work tridimensionally. We just recognize that sound waves that enter our ears in a certain way tend to come from X direction. Softwares like Dolby Atmos and even the sound engineers themselves can work with that information and add spatiality in a way that speakers will never be able to replicate. And this technology will only evolve with time.
The crosstalk you mentioned, however, is another form of "dirtyness" that can me desireable in music and is still a big argument for speakers, if you are into it.
>>90956730
I think grados are great because of their unique sound signature and funny idiosyncrasies, but they are crap headphones, anon.

posts.sub: Glacies - A sane and small linux/OS
posts.com:
A sane linux/OS in the building:
own non-posix libc (safe system library)
own coreutils
own posix libc, actually a compat layer (simia)
musl-based (may merge with simia)
s6 init
functional package manager
reproducible "redo"(djb) build system
scripts in execline
mksh as sh
(follow in the details the package in the arbor repo)

Its next step is to add arcan (already done in private, just finishing details), and soon a GUI installer.

Read more about and in bigger details at: https://eltaninos.org

If you wanna join the community for now prefer the matrix room, the IRC future is unsure (I may change the server or at least confirm ownership of the current one)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90935617
>Without reproducible builds, you'd have to trust a single person rather than just trust that the whole group hasn't been compromised at once.
A package has 6 people verifying it. 5 of them report that the hash checks out. Number 3 reports that he got a different hash, but number 4 informs number 3 that he probably messed something up while compiling it.
>Do you install the package?


If the answer is "no," then your machine is compromised because that guy just messed something up and that was a critical security update to patch a remote root exploit.

If the answer is "yes," then your machine is compromised because the 5 positive responses were the same malicious actor posting from various shill accounts.

It's entirely reasonable to assume the worst case for either option, because there are a lot of packages out there, and given enough time in this system you will eventually run into both scenarios. So in the end, the reproducible builds doesn't actually solve the problem and it all continues to boil down to a question of trust. On top of that, there's all sort of new problems that the system creates, so the answer to this question that no one asked goes a lot deeper than the mechanics of the reproducible builds themselves:
>What exactly is the system for people to report the hashes of the packages they compile?
>How many people do you actually expect the compile the package in a reproducible way? (ie no patches to the source code, no compiler optimizations, basically can't do any of the things that make people decide to compile themselves rather than install the binary package)
>How do you communicate to users how many times the package has passed/failed reproduction?
>How do you communicate to users *which* people have attempted to reproduce the package?
>How do users gain knowledge about which of these verifiers to trust in the case of a disagreement?

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90935896
2/2

All this reproducibility crap does is change package management from what we have today to a 1990s warez bbs where people post sketchy binaries and then other people bicker about whether it's a virus or not. It's not a step forward; it's useless at best, and at worse it's markedly worse if it means that the trusted individuals currently building packages for a distro stop performing that job because now they can let everyone else handle it. Trust is not a thing to be democratized. The way you democratize things is by removing the need for trust, which is not what you get from reproducible builds.

;; a comment macro for elisp (like clojure)
;; >>87116763
;; https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/comment
(defmacro comment (&rest body) nil)

;; https://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/ThreadMacroFromClojure
(defmacro -> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append (list (car form) result)
                           (cdr form))))))

(defmacro ->> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append form (list result))))))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90905561
Yeah, so the idea is to reimplement a modern web browser from the ground up in a single extensible layer using lisp. Obviously you're sol if you want to use the normal stack(though it MAY be possible to do some wizardry, I'm not hopeful for a magical open source html rendering engine anytime soon), so instead you use something else, probably sexps, maybe byte compile and compressed. Now you've basically reinvented HTML+CSS+JS. Did you do a better job? Maybe. And then you've got to network all this, and it's obviously going to have to be p2p since lets face it, it'll never be popular enough for a server ecosystem to make sense. Best way to do that is a DHT, maybe a skipgraph, you've now reinvented DNS, but much slower and more complicated since it needs to run on normal machines and not optically accelerated ASICs.
Lets say you finish it, you've got your perfect networked searchable all lisp ecosystem you can hook into from any computer anywhere in the world. How do you run programs not written in lisp? Now you've got to make untold amounts of libraries, hooks, boilerplate, etc... all in multiple other languages across lots of architectures just to attempt running the stuff.

Meanwhile, WASM already runs in browsers, it's based on sexps, operates off the normal internet, runs on all platforms, and works as a compilation target for all existing languages so old software can be directly compiled into WASM and run both in the browser and directly on bare metal. All the work has already been done, you can go try it out right now.

Obviously the answer is to take WASM and use it to build your lisp ecosystem idea, but currently it doesn't have GC or memory management, so everyone's stuck in limbo waiting for the ability for the ability of modules to create and execute other modules. Once that gets going it's just a matter of implementing a simple framework and you've got a single page operating system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90907912
Not platform interop, PROGRAM interop. If OTHER programs can also be compiled into wasm you can use the wasm interface to do cross machine IPC. Basically, because it all runs on the same virtual machine, you can ship the memory state around and reuse it without doing any translation, just like CL images. So you can run autocad in wasm on your machine, then pause the system, zip the vm state, send it to another computer, and continue from where you left off.
Or, if you implement an entire os in wasm, you could hibernate your entire system into a file, and using those augmented hyperlinks I mentioned before, remotely back it up, open and run it, dissassemble and step through it, etc...
The reason you want to actually use wasm instead of just compiling to it or compiling to x86 is in order to use these high level features your program has to KNOW it's running in wasm and how wasm modules/memories work and how to run them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90907979
Really that's just showing the superiority of interpreters and the tyranny of compiled assembly. If I'm running 15 layered javascript operating systems and using 15 GB of memory and 1kw of power to run a webshit calculator, the performance gains of compilers are moot. Who fucking cares if it takes 1000 times as long to crunch numbers if my computer is 10,000,000 times faster?
Sure, don't try to do graphics with an interpreter, BUT THE CPU DOESN'T DO THAT ANYWAY! The commands get COMPILED TO SHADER CODE! So all the graphics and numbercrunching shit can just be compiled for the GPU, and all general purpose CPU bound code can be interpreted!
Boom, 90% of all programs are now irrelevant and obsolete!
>don't need compilers
>don't need process control since you can cram entire vm images into continuations
>don't need multithreading libraries, just run one interpreter per core, all the images are single threaded
>don't need containerization, ALL PROCESSES are containers
>don't need access control, if you've got the link for data you have access, if you don't you can't reach it since it doesn't even exist as far as you're concerned
>don't need a browser, all your os level programs are trivially networked and distributed, you can replace a website with a program image and automatically download it, run it in a sandboxed container, and have it access server side data itself
>don't need suspend, hibernate, shutdown, restart, etc... since your entire system state is just a file

>better building blocks than purely manipulating strings on buffers?
terrible idea. everything being strings in buffers is like the best part of emacs. i think a better way to get more structured interpretations of the buffer is to implement internal mechanisms that allow you to collapse parts of the buffer. e.g. say you want to apply org-mode to all comments in the buffer. you should be able to collapse all the code sections so that when org-mode runs it appears as though its in a buffer of plain org-mode text. efficiently doing so is probably a difficult problem. you could rip out the text you want and put it in another buffer then transplant it back but thats probably slow.

i don't think this is exactly the kind of structure the mage guy has in mind though. he doesn't want structured reinterpretations of a buffer, he wants text to not be ascii streams at all and to stuff it in terrible tree representations and possibly other structures for muh notes. i want to be able to reuse text editing code in buffers where said text i want to run that code on is mixed with other content and contains other syntax and line prefixes i want to ignore. the fact that org-mode already parses buffers into trees is one of its biggest flaws.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90915259
Yup, CL has SET. The advantage that SET has compared to SETF or SETQ is that SET is a real function: the first argument is evaluated, just like any other, and it has to produce a symbol, which can be obtained by evaluating any arbitrary subexpression. In fact, the target of the assignment can thus be determined dynamically.

Now, in practice, everyone uses SETF 99.99% of the time in CL, which is the correct thing to do. But having a function like SET can be useful for some edge cases.

>
(set! (if (my-pred?) 'foo 'bar) "some value")

hmmm
what if you made a macro to do that? something like this, but in scheme. i can't into hygienic scheme macros so here is what i came up with in CL:
(defun wrap-clause (clause)
  (destructuring-bind (pred sym val) clause
    `(if ,pred (setf ,sym ,val))))

(defun nest-clauses (clauses)
  (reduce (lambda (c acc) (append c (list acc)))
          clauses :from-end t))

(defmacro cond-setf (val-form &body clauses)
  (let ((val (gensym)))
    `(let ((,val ,val-form))
       ,(nest-clauses
         (mapcar (lambda (c) (wrap-clause (append c `(,val))))
                 clauses)))))

it works like this
(cond-setf "some value"
  ((pred-1?) foo)
  ((pred-2?) bar)
  (t         baz))

turns into
(LET ((#:G366 "some value"))
  (IF (PRED-1?)
      (SETF FOO #:G366)
      (IF (PRED-2?)
          (SETF BAR #:G366)
          (IF T
              (SETF BAZ #:G366)))))

>>90930175
Common Lisp!
#|
file: test.txt

S | Repository     | Name           | Version       | Arch
--+----------------+----------------+---------------+-------
y |  repo_1        |  package_1     | version_1     | x86_64
n |  repo_2        |  package_2     | version_2     | x86_64
y |  repo_3        |  package_3     | version_3     | x86_64

|#

(defun get-packages ()
  (mapcar #'parse-package
          (cddr (uiop:run-program '("cat" "test.txt") :output :lines))))

(defun parse-package (p)
  (labels ((emptyp (s) (equal s "")))
    (let ((vals (remove-if #'emptyp (uiop:split-string p :separator " |")))
          (props '(:installed :repo :name :version :arch)))
      (mapcan #'list props vals))))

(defun get-package-prop (packages prop)
  (mapcar (lambda (p) (getf p prop)) packages))

(defparameter *packages* (get-packages))

(get-package-prop *packages* :installed) ;=> ("y" "n" "y")
(get-package-prop *packages* :repo)      ;=> ("repo_1" "repo_2" "repo_3")
(get-package-prop *packages* :name)      ;=> ("package_1" "package_2" "package_3")
(get-package-prop *packages* :version)   ;=> ("version_1" "version_2" "version_3")
(get-package-prop *packages* :arch)      ;=> ("x86_64" "x86_64" "x86_64")

(defun double-palindrome-p (str)
  (loop for i from 1 to (length str)
        for sub1 = (subseq str 0 i)

                (equal sub2 (reverse sub2)))
