posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90946836
Here's the _why_ of "don't use doom".
Doom emacs provides to a noob a set of opaque (to a noob) config files and macros and tools. You use these tools and uncomment text in a config file to make doom do what you want. The moment you want to add some elisp you found somewhere to make your emacs work a certain way, doom will start fighting you.
A starter pack like prelude is a better choice. It's just regular elisp the way you would write it as a normal user. It's a bit much to look at at first because unlike doom where you just modify the one config file, prelude's config is broken into multiple files. Prelude is also a nice choice if you want to roll your own config. The way it's broken into multiple files in lisp/ directory that are (require)'d in init.el is likely the same strategy you'd eventually land on if you roll your own config.
Prelude (or any other small starter pack) + a pdf of mastering emacs will be the most effective onboarding and it's not gonna leave you with wasted project-specific knowledge specific like doom / spacemacs.
Finally I'd like to add that in general the more you get to know emacs the less you will actually want in your init. Mine has shrunk slowly and consistently over the years and now it's really just a couple programming major modes, vertico, and corfu. Eglot for LSP and use-package are bundled with emacs29 too so my config will shrink even more in the coming year.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90955337
it's gonna be hard to explain, but once it "clicks" you'll understand everything at once.

think about it this way: lisp is homoiconic, lisp code and lisp data have the same 'shape'. so, the same way you can build this list:
(list 1 2 3 4 5)

you could also build a list like this:
(list + 2 2)

the code above would return the list (+ 2 2), which looks just like a function application, right? so if you eval (+ 2 2), it would be as if you had written (+ 2 2) as code

macros do that. think of a macro as a function to build a list, and that list will be evaluated as code. the error in your macro is exactly this, the macro is evaluating this expression
(function argument)

but you don't want to evaluate it, you want to return it.

a simple fix would be 
`(,function ,argument)
, but you need to understand what's happening conceptually.

>So `(,function ,argument) = (list function argument)?
no. this code, in scheme, would expand to 
(quasiquote (unquote function) (unquote argument))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90955337
A macro goes through two stages of evaluation:
First, it is expanded. This usually happens before anything else -- possibly at compile time. Now, when we evaluate that macro, what would we get?
(function argument) => What is function? What is argument? Those haven't been defined yet.

So, like the other post said, we need to quote it first. Then, when that is evaluated, what do we get?
'(function argument) => (function argument)

That's right, if you evaluate a quoted expression, you get back the literal form. No errors or undefined variables.
Of course, that's not very useful because we don't care about "function" or "argument", we want what those values are going to stand for, thus:
`(,function ,argument) => ([function] [argument])

By "unquoting" the two variables we are telling the macro expander to replace them with whatever those values are *eventually* going to be, but we don't care about them right now.

After the whole expansion ordeal is finished, the result replaces your macro call. This is the reason why we want a macro to return a quoted form, and not the actual result like functions do. So:
(print "Hello World")
(my-macro function argument)
(+ 1 1)

Would simply become:
(print "Hello World")
(function argument)
(+ 1 1)


And finally comes the second stage, where the expanded result of your macro is once again evaluated, but this time together with all the rest of your program, as if it had been there all along.

>>90961533
You mean edits of AI gen'd images?
It's not really that hard. You can just port shit to photoshop, do light redraw/edit the portions you want, doesn't even need to match super well, then take it to img2img and run the exact prompt on the same seed with a fairly low denoise. It more or less gives it a few passes and makes everything consistent.
You can also do dumb massage technique shit where you run it through img2img with varying prompts trying to gacha into random shit you might prefer while keeping it at a fairly similar overall visual structure with slightly higher denoise and can then take bits and pieces and layer into photoshop to cobble shit together and THEN run it through the initial seed at a lower denoise.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90948189
>Anon... the function declared in the printf.c uses the __vfprintf_internal function for formatting...
Yes, but it doesn't make sense in his argument. Macros are not part of the function, they are declared separately. The code doesn't show contain just a function with no macros, it contains multiple functions and macros. The code doesn't even contain the printf code, but internal functions that are used by it. Not a single thing he has said so far is true.

>The other anon is wrong because he thinks the entirety of vfprintf-internal.c willb e actually used but that's not the case usually, it depends on how you invoke the printf() function, the compiler handles the rest
This is true, but that's not even everything. In last post he claimed that println! being a macro makes it more limiting than printf that is a function. Which is complete negation of the reality. println! is more flexible precisely because it is a macro, you can extend it and write your own formatters for your own custom types and it will just work with every macro that uses argument formatting. On the other hand printf can only format fixed number of built in types and that's pretty much it. The only "advantage" that printf has is ability to pass non-static format string, but this is not a good idea in practice, it's easy to cause undefined behavior or even a vulnerability this way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90948490
println! requires first argument to be a string literal.
printf as far as I know accepts an runtime string as format string.
So in theory you could construct a format string in runtime and then pass it to printf because parsing of the format string happens in runtime. In Rust, format strings are parsed during compilation so this is not possible, you need to use a different method, for example runtime_fmt crate that provides that functionality.
But I do not think this is a good practice in general. Never had to do it personally anyway.

Assuming that you enabled 2FA on your account, the attacker should not compromise it. If you didnt, the will most likely log in to your account, enable 2FA that THEY can control and start browsing throught your emails/resetting your passwords for other services. In this case, you are absolutely fucked. The only think you can do is to try to reach google support, maybe try to start a drama about that on orange reddit (aka HN) and quite being a lazy, ignorant, illiterate faggot.

If they will fail to login to your email, they will probably check if your password can be used with your other account. Using the same password more than once is the most stupid thing you can do, but they know that some people still do that anyway, and they take advantage of that. Sometimes I kinda feel sorry for them, but desu they deserve that to learn a fucking lesson and start giving a thing about their accounts.

>>90956824
First line turns off the mouse
Next two lines make it look like vi
4th line makes new files have 0a newlines
next two lines make the tab key insert two spaces. Note that many users also set tabstop in this situation which is wrong, you should always leave that at 8 or plenty of documents will break including the help pages.
7th line turns off wrapping. If you want wrapping you should set linebreak because the default settings just wrap in the middle of a word lmao.
For the next three lines, the 1st marks trailing whitespace red, the second tabstop chars red, and the 3rd the 81st column red. Because all of those are bad.
The autocommand does two things when I :q - deletes the shada/log/bullshit dump directories (I used to manually disable a bunch of the stuff that used them but got tired of enumerating shit) and sets the cursor back to what I prefer for being at the command line, since nvim will have turned it into a box when I opened it.
>giga bloat
That's the entirety of my setup, I don't have a single plugin. Plenty of (n)vim users have bloated setups but I'm not one of them, in fact my config file is fewer lines than most vim users lmao see sensible.vim >>90948769

>>90957077
#define ROUNDS 10
#define STEP (1.0 / ROUNDS)
#define BLUE L'+'
#define WHITE L'-'

static int
get_percentage_rounds(double percentage, wchar_t rounds[ROUNDS]) {
  size_t i;
  double j;

  if (percentage > 1.0)
    return 0;

  for (i = 0, j = 0.0; j < percentage; i++, j += STEP)
    rounds[i] = L'+';

  for (; i < ROUNDS; i++)
    rounds[i] = L'-';

  return 1;
}

No there's no script to do it that will work for any random game.
